acronyms.VW: Visual Watch - lookout observation using eyes/binoculars
acronyms.TDC: Torpedo Data Computer - mechanical analog computer for calculating torpedo firing solutions
acronyms.TDM: Torpedo Detection Modification - passive sonar add-on with CRT display for detecting incoming torpedoes and enemy sonar pinging; showed contacts as traces on an oscilloscope-like screen
acronyms.SD: SD Radar - air search radar (detected aircraft)
acronyms.SJ: SJ Radar - surface search radar (detected ships)
acronyms.TBT: Target Bearing Transmitter - optical device for determining target bearing
acronyms.APR: APR Radar Detector - detected enemy radar emissions
acronyms.BT: Bathythermograph - instrument measuring water temperature vs. depth; produced a 'BT card' showing thermal layers that affected sonar performance
acronyms.DRAI: Dead Reckoning Analyzer Indicator - electromechanical navigation device that continuously calculated and displayed the ship's position based on course and speed inputs
acronyms.DRT: Dead Reckoning Tracer - navigation plotting device
acronyms.QC: QC Sonar - echo-ranging (active) sonar for detecting submerged objects
acronyms.JP: JP Sonar - early passive listening sonar with a single trainable hydrophone head
acronyms.JK: JK Sonar - improved passive listening sonar with better sensitivity and bearing discrimination than JP
acronyms.OOD: Officer of the Deck - officer in charge of the ship's watch, responsible for navigation, safety, and carrying out the captain's orders
acronyms.JOOD: Junior Officer of the Deck - assistant to the OOD, typically a junior officer gaining experience
acronyms.CTF: Commander, Task Force - operational command authority
acronyms.FBT: Fuel Ballast Tank - ballast tank used to store fuel oil for extended range
acronyms.MBT: Main Ballast Tank - tanks flooded to submerge and blown to surface
acronyms.PC: Patrol Craft - small coastal patrol vessel
acronyms.AF: Store Ship - naval auxiliary vessel carrying provisions and supplies
acronyms.mcs: Megacycles per second - old term for megahertz (MHz), radio frequency unit
acronyms.kcs: Kilocycles per second - old term for kilohertz (kHz), radio frequency unit
acronyms.CW: Continuous Wave - Morse code radio transmission mode
acronyms.HIJMS: His Imperial Japanese Majesty's Ship - prefix for Imperial Japanese Navy vessels
acronyms.EC: Enemy Confirmed - sinking/identity verified through intelligence or observation
acronyms.EU: Enemy Unconfirmed - probable sinking but not definitively confirmed
acronyms.MFM: Mast-Funnel-Mast - ship silhouette profile showing mast, smokestack, then mast from bow to stern
acronyms.MIS: Miscellaneous - classification for smaller unclassified vessels
acronyms.SMC: Small Miscellaneous Craft - classification for small auxiliary vessels

aircraft.Betty: Mitsubishi G4M - Japanese twin-engine medium bomber
aircraft.Zeke: Mitsubishi A6M Zero - Allied code name for Zero fighter
aircraft.Val: Aichi D3A - Japanese carrier-based dive bomber
aircraft.Kate: Nakajima B5N - Japanese carrier-based torpedo bomber
aircraft.Emily: Kawanishi H8K - Japanese four-engine flying boat
aircraft.Mavis: Kawanishi H6K - Japanese four-engine flying boat
aircraft.Nell: Mitsubishi G3M - Japanese twin-engine medium bomber
aircraft.Sally: Mitsubishi Ki-21 - Japanese Army twin-engine heavy bomber
aircraft.Lily: Kawasaki Ki-48 - Japanese Army twin-engine light bomber
aircraft.Dinah: Mitsubishi Ki-46 - Japanese twin-engine reconnaissance aircraft
aircraft.Tojo: Nakajima Ki-44 Shoki - Japanese Army single-engine interceptor fighter
aircraft.PBY: Consolidated PBY Catalina - U.S. patrol flying boat
aircraft.PBM: Martin PBM Mariner - U.S. patrol flying boat
aircraft.Liberator: Consolidated B-24 - U.S. four-engine heavy bomber
aircraft.B-24: Consolidated B-24 Liberator - U.S. four-engine heavy bomber
aircraft.B-26: Martin B-26 Marauder - U.S. twin-engine medium bomber
aircraft.Hellcat: Grumman F6F - U.S. Navy carrier-based fighter
aircraft.Helldiver: Curtiss SB2C - U.S. Navy carrier-based dive bomber
aircraft.SBD: Douglas SBD Dauntless - U.S. Navy dive bomber

jargon.went deep: Submerged to maximum safe depth to avoid detection or depth charges
jargon.battle surface: Surfacing to engage enemy with deck guns
jargon.rigged for depth charge: Secured all equipment and prepared ship for depth charge attack
jargon.rigged for silent running: Minimized all noise to avoid sonar detection
jargon.periscope depth: Shallow depth (about 60 feet) where periscope can be used
jargon.making approach: Maneuvering into position for torpedo attack
jargon.angle on the bow: Angle between target's heading and line of sight to submarine
jargon.gyro angle: Angle torpedo must turn after firing to hit target
jargon.spread: Firing multiple torpedoes at different angles to increase hit probability
jargon.screw: Propeller (often refers to sound of enemy propellers)
jargon.escort: Warship providing protection - either enemy ships guarding a convoy, or friendly ships accompanying Cod in/out of port
jargon.convoy: Group of merchant ships traveling together with escorts
jargon.lifeguard duty: Submarine stationed to rescue downed aviators
jargon.blow: Force water out of ballast tanks with compressed air to surface
jargon.vent: Open ballast tank vents to flood and submerge
jargon.bow and arrow: Torpedo shot fired straight ahead at an oncoming target - difficult due to narrow profile and rapidly closing range
jargon.sampan: Small flat-bottomed Asian boat, typically used for fishing or coastal transport

places.Pearl Harbor: U.S. Naval Base, Hawaii - main Pacific Fleet submarine base
places.Midway: Midway Atoll - forward submarine base in central Pacific
places.Fremantle: Port in Western Australia - Allied submarine base
places.Balboa: Port at Pacific end of Panama Canal
places.Bungo Suido: Strait between Japanese islands of Kyushu and Shikoku
places.Luzon Strait: Strait between Taiwan and Philippines - major shipping lane
places.Empire waters: Waters near the Japanese home islands
places.Majuro: Majuro Atoll, Marshall Islands - major U.S. Navy forward base and anchorage captured in 1944
places.Thwartway: Historical name for Sangiang Island, in Sunda Strait between Java and Sumatra
places.Northwatcher: Navigation landmark (island/rock) in the northern approaches to Sunda Strait
places.Two Brothers: Navigation landmark (islands/rocks) in the northern approaches to Sunda Strait
places.Takao: Japanese name for Kaohsiung - major port on southwest coast of Formosa (Taiwan)

equipment.Mark 14: Standard U.S. submarine torpedo (had reliability issues early in war)
equipment.Mark 18: Electric torpedo (no wake, harder to detect)
equipment.Torpex: Torpedo explosive - 50% more powerful than TNT by mass, used in WWII torpedo warheads
equipment.pit log: Pitometer log - speed indicator using Pitot tube to measure water pressure and display speed in knots
